blocks.text: Resilience and recovery plans are only effective if they are regularly tested. Written procedures that have never been exercised often fail under real-world conditions.
Testing includes backup restoration drills, failover simulations, and disaster recovery exercises. These tests identify configuration errors, missing dependencies, and procedural gaps.
Tabletop exercises simulate incidents through discussion, allowing teams to practice decision-making and communication. Technical exercises validate system behavior during failures.
Testing also verifies that recovery objectives can be met. If recovery time exceeds business requirements, architecture and processes must be improved.
Continuous improvement depends on post-test reviews and documentation updates. Lessons learned must be incorporated into future designs and training programs.
